ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about democratic backsliding (obviously), both in theoretical terms and by studying individual cases. We analyzed a lot of methodology and research, and received feedback on our own.

I got to learn alot about Democratic Backsliding and this course really gave insight into how academia is because all of our papers and discussions focused on analyzing very specific topics in detail as opposed to broad topics with a lack of detail, and that was very helpful.
This was a really interesting course on democratic backsliding in a globalized context.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There could have been one less paper. The readings at times were a but unmanageable as well.

strengths- content is interesting and very relevant to current times, really helped improve my research skills, allows for flexibility on the assignments
weaknesses- workload was insanely high, poorly organized, prof svolik designed a really unrealistic syllabus and constantly made changes to it, expectations were not clear, reading load was insanely high even though we usually wouldn't cover more than three during class, the amount of papers was also ridiculously high

Professor Svolik was very good at facilitating discussions, the course material was interesting. The only thing that could be improved is just to not syllabus have the syllabus change frequently. Also, I would have loved more comments on my essays.
Professor Svolik is very knowleadgable in this field. The research is quite interesting, and Professor Svolik has a good nature about the material.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Frankly I think prof svolik did a really poor job designing this course this semester. He told us at the first class meeting that he anticipates discussion over zoom to be worse than in person, and would give us additional assignments to make up for this. Giving more assignments than usual when students are living through what is probably the most stressful time in their life is ridiculous. The original syllabus had 6 5-page papers and a 15 page final paper, which he reduced to 4 5-page papers and the final paper once we were halfway through the semester and he realized that there was no way to reasonably distribute 6 assignments. He claimed that he expected these papers to take us about an hour... in what world does a 5 page paper take an hour? It frequently seemed that he was so disconnected from the realities of being a student. The due dates for these four assignments were also poorly planned out, and we ended up having 2 5-page papers and the final paper due all in the last month of the semester. One of these papers was due over Thanksgiving break, which was incredibly unfair considering that students had not had a break for 12 weeks, and another paper was due the week after. In spite of anticipating that discussion over zoom would be worse than in person, prof svolik made no effort to facilitate discussion and class meetings were awkward and not engaging.
This course was tough to engage with virtually and from home.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No. I would not recommend taking a course with prof svolik in an online format. This class was by far more stressful than any other political science course I've taken, the readings were dense and pretty much all written by white men, class discussion was not interesting, the amount of assignments was absurd, and prof svolik was very unorganized and unresponsive. Even though I found the readings interesting, I think there are far better courses with better instructors to take at Yale and I honestly dreaded going to this class every week.

Yes, this is such a great course to learn about democratic backsliding and Professor Svolik is very insightful with all his discussion and comments. The material is very interesting and very relevant to today's world with the rise in populism.
